We're honestly probably heading for a hyper-specialized hardware future
Over time, we got more of the general use components that make up a computer today, but now they're starting to add specialized hardware subsets to the general purpose parts
we already do that though- we just include them onboard
What I mean is, we're going to identify certain subsets of operations that are extremely common, and then start creating hardware that does that exclusively
but then you end up with controller issues and traffic issues
It'll probably fall to the developers to program for the hardware
creating extra special parts on their own is a hardware thing not a software thing
Depending on what said controllers and such are meant to do, they may or may not require extra effort to program for.
Just because RTX video cards have ray tracing cores doesn't mean everything uses them
There's two sides to it like noodle said.
But they greatly increase raytracing capabilities of programs that code for them
the devices - that control things on hardware- are hardware- they have to tell things to do things on a hardware level
The decompression hardware in the PS5's SSD will be specifically for the very compressed files that games use to save space

you cant program them- they are hardware- you run programs on hardware

I meant that we'll start including hardware in addition to what we have that will be specialized
and im saying we already do that- but you cant do that for everything or else you end up with a nightmare to combine together
Like how GPU's now have ray tracing cores, deep-learning / AI cores, etc
the more separate things you have to deal with the more traffic you make - the more crashes you get when one thing comes in before another
Obviously you don't want specialized hardware for *everything*
like the fact that games themselves on old consoles are optimized and developed specifically for the speed of the CPU clock
But there are intensive tasks that will benefit greatly

it can decompile faster because of multicores and plenty of threads so traffic is not an issue

You play Simon Jarrett, a man who was in a car accident that left him with a brain injury
that sounds like something a robot would say
On May 2, 2015, Simon went to an office complex to get a brain scan done by Dr. Mushi (not a doctor at the time, this brain scan was part of his thesis work)
The idea is, if they scan the pathways inside the brain, they could better understand the damage, and hopefully craft a personalized treatment to help repair the brain
You sit down in the chair to get the brain scan done, and the next thing you know you're in a different room, different chair
And now apparently it's the year flipping 2103,a nd yer a robot Simon
You later meet Carl Semken, a man who's a machine but thinks he's a man
You can find his corpse nearby in a hall
Later you meet Catherine, whose also a machine but is aware she's a machine and she cracks open this whole brain scan debacle
Quite literally, those brain scans creates a complete copy of your consciousness, memories and all
Oh yeah, there's also murder machines and corpses running around trying to kill you
"I did not consent to being robo cloned!"
